highlights:
Qualifications:
 Bachelor’s degree or equivalent experience and at least ten (10) years of progressive leadership experience in the area of non-profit/association management, fundraising, external affairs, community engagement, civic engagement, field organizing, and partnership cultivation;, At least five (5) years of experience in staff, National Board, volunteer committee and contractor coordination and management;, Current National level partnership and external affairs relationships and experience;, Ability to forge strong relationships with strategic partners;, Entrepreneurial drive and demonstrated ability to achieve goals;, Experience with state, national civic engagement and DEI issues;, Excellent leadership, strategic planning, interpersonal, and communications skills, Expertise in managing relationships with key stakeholders, including individuals, corporations, and foundations, Ability to develop and execute comprehensive, integrated partnership strategies and programs, Ability to build rapport and provide assistance to high-profile external constituents as well as internal staff;, Experience preparing and managing budgets;, Strong organizational, project management, and financial management skills, Demonstrated ability to raise funds from a variety of sources, including major gifts, grants, and events, Familiarity with civil rights and social justice issues, and commitment to advancing the NAACP's mission, Bachelor's degree in a related field, or equivalent experience; advanced degree preferre, Note: The qualifications listed above are intended to represent a broad range of potential skills and experience that may be relevant to the position, 
Responsibilities:
 The Vice President, Partnerships, and Community, drives the strategic direction, development, and execution of all partnerships, community, identity programs, and external affairs and projects of the association, They will build and oversee key initiatives related to the mission, vision, and values of the NAACP, These include but are not limited to partnerships, leadership programs, identity-based programs, and special projects responsible for establishing, cultivating, and expanding relationships with key partners, including corporations, foundations, organizations, and individuals in support of NAACP's mission
